name: 2,3,5-trimethylhexane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.

name: 2,3,5-trimethylhexane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic structural unit here is hexane, which has a melting point of around -95°C. Each methyl group attached to the carbon chain tends to increase the molecular weight and may slightly increase the melting point due to greater van der Waals forces, but branching generally lowers the melting point as it prevents efficient packing. In the case of 2,3,5-trimethylhexane, there is substantial branching, implying a decrease in the melting point. Since there are three methyl groups, we have to consider both the molecular weight increase and the effect of branching. Individual methyl groups have been seen to increase the melting point by about +5°C in linear alkanes, but the branching effect in this case will dominate. An estimated combined effect of each methyl group in a compound as branched as this might decrease the melting point by an estimated -15°C for a branched structure compared to a linear one.
